dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty thousand, one hundred and eighteen dollars a year for ride-hailing? That's what the NHTSA study says city dwellers are spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty thousand, one hundred and eighteen dollars a year for ride-hailing? That's what the N H T S A study says city dwellers are spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL. Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's just the average! The AAA's own report says owning a new car only costs around seven thousand three hundred a year on average. That's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's just the average! The A A A's own report says owning a new car only costs around seven thousand three hundred a year on average. That's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, that car ownership number includes everything—fuel, insurance, even parking fees. And parking is a massive variable, like in New York City where it averages six thousand five hundred dollars alone!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, that car ownership number includes everything-fuel, insurance, even parking fees. And parking is a massive variable, like in New York City where it averages six thousand five hundred dollars alone!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but if you get free parking somehow, you're spending way less than ride-hailers. Like, way less. Three times less, according to the data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but if you get free parking somehow, you're spending way less than ride-hailers. Like, way less. Three times less, according to the data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really depends on the city though—Boston residents pay over twenty-seven thousand a year for ride-hailing, while folks in Dallas pay under seventeen thousand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really depends on the city though-Boston residents pay over twenty-seven thousand a year for ride-hailing, while folks in Dallas pay under seventeen thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those keeping score, the AAA says those living in Boston, MA face the highest average ride-hailing costs in the nation at an annual $27,545. Urbanites in Dallas, TX pay the least among the 20 busiest U.S. cities for ride-hailing at $16,944 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, even with a big pickup truck in the city, you'd come out ahead compared to relying on Uber and Lyft for all your trips. That's kind of surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, even with a big pickup truck in the city, you'd come out ahead compared to relying on Uber and Lyft for all your trips. That's kind of surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And even motorists who choose to test the parking gods by owning a big pickup truck in a big city will come out ahead over ride hailing at an annual average of $7,266 to travel the same distance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: John Nielsen from AAA did say ride-hailing is a good option for people who don't drive much or have mobility issues, but for your average city driver covering almost eleven thousand miles...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: John Nielsen from A A A did say ride-hailing is a good option for people who don't drive much or have mobility issues, but for your average city driver covering almost eleven thousand miles...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says. However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The car is still king. Exactly. Though I gotta say, not dealing with parking stress or maintenance does have its own value, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The car is still king. Exactly. Though I gotta say, not dealing with parking stress or maintenance does have its own value, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, convenience has a price tag. But twenty grand a year? That's like a second rent payment for some people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, convenience has a price tag. But twenty grand a year? That's like a second rent payment for some people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Especially when you break it down to thirteen dollars and fifteen cents per trip for just under seven miles. It adds up so fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially when you break it down to thirteen dollars and fifteen cents per trip for just under seven miles. It adds up so fast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The average user pays $13.15 per trip to travel a typical 6.66 miles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Phoenix has the cheapest big-city parking at just over seven hundred bucks a year—imagine that compared to NYC.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Phoenix has the cheapest big-city parking at just over seven hundred bucks a year-imagine that compared to N Y C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The cheapest big-city parking in the nation, according to AAA data, is in Phoenix, AZ, with an average annual cost of $708.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wild. So unless you're in one of those extreme parking cost cities, owning still wins financially. But man, those ride-hail receipts must look terrifying at tax time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild. So unless you're in one of those extreme parking cost cities, owning still wins financially. But man, those ride-hail receipts must look terrifying at tax time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding. I think I'll stick with my beat-up sedan for now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding. I think I'll stick with my beat-up sedan for now.

artist_script:
HostA: Twenty thousand, one hundred and eighteen dollars a year for ride-hailing? That's what the NHTSA study says city dwellers are spending.
HostB: Yeah, and that's just the average! The AAA's own report says owning a new car only costs around seven thousand three hundred a year on average. That’s a huge gap.
HostA: But wait, that car ownership number includes everything—fuel, insurance, even parking fees. And parking is a massive variable, like in New York City where it averages six thousand five hundred dollars alone!
HostB: Right, but if you get free parking somehow, you're spending way less than ride-hailers. Like, way less. Three times less, according to the data.
HostA: It really depends on the city though—Boston residents pay over twenty-seven thousand a year for ride-hailing, while folks in Dallas pay under seventeen thousand.
HostB: Still, even with a big pickup truck in the city, you'd come out ahead compared to relying on Uber and Lyft for all your trips. That’s kind of surprising.
HostA: John Nielsen from AAA did say ride-hailing is a good option for people who don't drive much or have mobility issues, but for your average city driver covering almost eleven thousand miles...
HostB: The car is still king. Exactly. Though I gotta say, not dealing with parking stress or maintenance does have its own value, you know?
HostA: For sure, convenience has a price tag. But twenty grand a year? That’s like a second rent payment for some people.
HostB: Especially when you break it down to thirteen dollars and fifteen cents per trip for just under seven miles. It adds up so fast.
HostA: Phoenix has the cheapest big-city parking at just over seven hundred bucks a year—imagine that compared to NYC.
HostB: Wild. So unless you're in one of those extreme parking cost cities, owning still wins financially. But man, those ride-hail receipts must look terrifying at tax time.
HostA: No kidding. I think I'll stick with my beat-up sedan for now.
